newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia aims to liberalise T-bill market by end-'97.
newsitem.headline: Russia aims to liberalise T-bill market by end-'97.

text.p: Russia's central bank has set a timetable for the gradual liberalisation of non-resident access to the government securities market by the end of this year, a senior central bank official said on Monday.

"The most important decision is how, by the beginning of 1998, to end the limits on non-residents... From January 1 a foreigner can put in money and two days later, say, take it out," deputy chairman Alexander Potyomkin told a news conference.

Starting in May the central bank will reduce the minimum period for forward and option deals which non-residents are required to carry out when repatriating their investments in GKO discount Treasury bills or OFZ interest-bearing government bonds, a central bank statement said.
From January 1998 the requirement to conduct these forward or option deals will be abolished.

Also starting in May the authorities will begin to ease the requirement on commercial banks handling non-resident investments in government securities to offset some of these transactions with the central bank.
The central bank had used these compensatory transactions to influence the effective yield obtained by foreigners investing in the market.
